Low blood sugar can lead to dizziness. Eating a small snack or meal might help. Anxiety and hyperventilation can contribute to dizziness. Practice deep breathing to help calm your body. If your giddiness is severe, persistent, or accompanied by other symptoms such as fainting, confusion, headache, or vision changes, seek medical attention immediately.

Not drinking enough fluids can cause dizziness. Diabetes medications, especially insulin and some oral medications, can lower blood sugar levels too much, leading to dizziness. If you have a glucose meter, check your blood sugar level. If it’s low (usually below 70 mg/dL), consume fast-acting carbohydrates, such as fruit juice, glucose tablets, or candy.
